title: Disappearance Day of Srila Narottama Dasa | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | ISKCON Bangalore Sanga
speaker: HDG Srila Prabhupada

segments.text: Today is the disappearance day of Srila Narottam Das Thakur.
Let us hear his glorious biography from the Chaitanya Charita Amrita.
Srila Narottam Das Thakur, a preeminent Acharya in the Gaudiya Vaishnava tradition,
was an eternal associate of Lord Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu.
In his spiritual identity, he is known as Champaka Manjari,
an intimate maidservant of Srimati Radharani,
who eternally assists Sri Rupa Manjari in serving Radha and Krishna.
Out of compassion for the conditioned souls,
Champaka Manjari descended to earth as Narottam Das Thakur
in the village of Kheturi in present-day Bangladesh around the mid-16th century.
Narottama appeared on the full screen,
on the full moon day of Magha as the son of King Krishnananda Datta and Queen Narayani Devi.
His birth was marked by auspicious omens,
and the entire kingdom rejoiced with his father distributing generous charity to the local brahmanas.
Even as a child, Narottama demonstrated profound devotion
during his Annaprashana ceremony,
which is the first grain,
feeding ceremony for the infant child.
He refused to eat until the food was first offered to Lord Krishna,
thus teaching the sanctity of Prasadam.
An astrologer observing his divine features declared
that the child would become the greatest among men
and thus should be named Narottama.
Gifted with an extraordinary memory,
Narottama was a Shruti Dharam,
able to retain everything he heard.
He mastered Sanskrit, grammar and the Vedas with ease,
but his heart was fixed on serving Krishna.
Remaining a lifelong Brahmachari,
he was indifferent to the comforts of royal life.
Concerned by his growing detachment,
his parents placed guards to keep watch over him.
But Narottama's only happiness lay in hearing the divine pastimes of Lord Chaitanya and Lord Nityananda,
narrated to him daily.
in hearing the divine pastimes of Lord Chaitanya and Lord Nityananda, narrated to him daily.
daily by Shri Krishnadas Kaviraj Goswami.
Immersed in remembrance of the Lord, he once had a dream
in which Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu instructed him to travel to Vrindavan.
When his father was away, Narottama escaped from home to fulfill the Lord's
instruction. As he journeyed toward Vrindavan, his
saintly nature attracted everyone's affection and people
offered him food and shelter along the way. Upon reaching
Vrindavan, he met Srila Jeeva Goswami and Srinivasa
Acharya. Their meeting was filled with spiritual
joy and affection and Narottama and Srinivasa soon became
inseparable friends united in their love for the Lord.
Srila Jeeva Goswami introduced Narottama to Shri Narottama.
Srila Jeeva Goswami introduced Narottama to Shri Loknath Goswami.
Narottama humbly fell at his feet and Loknath Goswami moved by his sincerity
blessed him and later agreed to initiate him.
Srila Jeeva Goswami also introduced Narottama to Shri Gopalabhatta Goswami
and Shri Bhuggadbhag Goswami who
received him affectionately. Narottama visited the holy temples of Rathadamoda
and Madan Mohan and upon seeing the samadhis of Rupa and Sanatana Goswamis, he appreciated their love for the Lord.
he wept uncontrollably in love and devotion.
Later with Srinivasa Acharya, he visited Radhakunda and Shamakunda
and received the blessings of Sri Raghunath Das Goswami
who was deeply touched by his devotion.
Under the care of Jeeva Goswami, Narottama studied deeply the scriptures of Bhakti
and soon became renowned for his humility, scholarship and realization.
Srila Lokarnath Goswami, seeing Narottama's pure-hearted service
finally initiated him into the chanting of the Maha Mantra.
His exceptional understanding of devotional literature
impressed all the Vaishnavas of Vrindavan
and Sri Jeeva Goswami bestowed upon him the title Sri Thakur Mahasaya.
From then on, he became a leading teacher and preacher in the Gaudiya Vaishnava movement.
Srila Prabhupada,
Prabhupada said of his songs,
The songs of Narottama Das Thakur are spiritual thunderbolts that crack open the heart.
They descend directly from the spiritual world.
Srila Narottama Das Thakur's two principal works are
Prarthana and Prema Bhakti Chandrika
which beautifully express the essence of Gaudiya Vaishnava philosophy
guiding devotees from Srinivasa Acharya to the spiritual world.
They have the ability to take to the higher stages of divine love.
Srila Narottama Das Thakur organized the grand Keturi Mahotsava festival
at his birthplace, the first large-scale Gaud Purnima celebration,

Srila Narottama Das Thakura organized the grand Keturi Mahotsava festival,
which is the birthplace of Mahotsava and is holy.

since that time, this festival has been celebrated in many different ways, many of them being being celebrated as main festivals, as spiritual festivals, as cultural festivals, as cultural festivals, as religious festivals, as political festivals, asza and religious festivals.
festival at his birthplace, the first large-scale God Purnima celebration
which commemorates Lord Chaitanya's appearance. This event united Lord
Chaitanya's followers from many regions and established the foundation for his
worship across Bengal. Although born into a Kayastha community, traditionally
considered of lower caste, Narottama became the spiritual master of thousands
including many learned brahmanas such as Ganga Narayan Chakravarthi and
Ramachandra Kaviraj. These exalted disciples humbly served him, acknowledging
his transcendental position. Despite criticism from caste conscious brahmanas,
Narottama remained compassionate, embracing everyone equally and
demonstrating that spiritual qualification is measured by devotion
not by birth. In his later life, Narottama became a spiritual master of the
old caste. This is the reason why he became a spiritual master of the new caste.
After his death, Narottama experienced deep separation from the Lord and his
associates. Having witnessed the departure of the six Goswamis, Srinivas
Acharya and Ramachandra Kaviraj, he poured his heart out in the famous song
Jai Anilo Prema Dhana, expressing grief over the loss of the great devotees who
brought divine love to the world. His disappearance was miraculous. Aware that
bathe him by pouring Ganga water over his body. As they did this, his body turned white like milk
and gradually melted into the sacred Ganges. Heartbroken but obedient, his disciples collected
the mixture of milk, tears, and Ganga water and enshrined it at Kheturi, where a beautiful
Samadhi was built, known as Dut Samadhi, the Samadhi of Milk. Srila Narottam Das Thakur remains
a radiant example of pure devotion, humility, and compassion. His life and songs reveal the heart
of Prema Bhakti, unconditional love for Krishna, and his teachings transcend all material distinctions.
Srila Prabhupada revered his bhajans as spiritual scripture and they continue to inspire generations
of devotees worldwide.
